page.title: List of Nobel laureates affiliated with Massachusetts Institute of Technology

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead.) #IABot (v2.0
revision.text:
[[File:Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) - panoramio.jpg|thumb|The Great Dome at MIT. As of October 2019, 97 Nobel laureates have been affiliated with MIT.]] This '''list of Nobel laureates affiliated with Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)''' comprehensively shows the alumni, faculty members as well as researchers of [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] who were awarded the [[Nobel Prize]] or the [[Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences]]. The Nobel Prizes, established by the 1895 will of [[Alfred Nobel]], are awarded to individuals who make outstanding contributions in the fields of [[Nobel Prize in Chemistry|Chemistry]], [[Nobel Prize in Literature|Literature]], [[Nobel Peace Prize|Peace]], [[Nobel Prize in Physics|Physics]], and [[Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine|Physiology or Medicine]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nobelprize.org/alfred_nobel/|title=Alfred Nobel – The Man Behind the Nobel Prize|publisher=Nobel Foundation|accessdate=18 May 2017}}</ref> An associated prize, the Sveriges Riksbank Prize in Economic Sciences in Memory of Alfred Nobel (commonly known as the [[Nobel Prize in Economics]]), was instituted by Sweden's central bank, [[Sveriges Riksbank]], in 1968 and first awarded in 1969.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/economic-sciences/|title=The Sveriges Riksbank Prize in Economic Sciences in Memory of Alfred Nobel|publisher=Nobel Foundation|accessdate=18 May 2017}}</ref>
{{As of|2019|October}}, 97 Nobel laureates have been affiliated with MIT. Among the 97 laureates, 96 are the laureates of the scientific Nobel Prizes and the Nobel Prize in Economics; 39 are MIT alumni (graduates and attendees) and 37 have been long-term academic members of the MIT faculty; and, subject-wise, 34 have won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences, more than any other subject. No MIT Nobel laureate has won the Nobel Prize in Literature. This list considers Nobel laureates as equal individuals and does not consider their various prize shares or if they received the prize more than once.<ref>{{cite web |title=Nobel Prize facts |url=https://www.nobelprize.org/prizes/facts/nobel-prize-facts |publisher=Nobel Foundation |accessdate=29 September 2019}}</ref>
== Inclusion criteria ==
=== General rules === [[File:MIT Stata Center-20070224.jpg|thumb|228x228px|Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] The affiliations of [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] in this list include all the official academic affiliations such as official academic employment and degree programs of the university. The official academic affiliations include alumni (graduates and attendees), long-term faculty members, and short-term academic staff.
Graduates are defined as those who hold [[Bachelor's degree|bachelor's]], [[Master's degree|master's]], [[doctorate]], or equivalent degrees from MIT, while attendees are those who studied at the institute, but did not complete the degree program or obtain a formal degree. All MIT degrees has been earned by academic labor, in that MIT has never awarded [[honorary degree]]s in any form.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/2001/commdegrees.html |title = No honorary degrees is an MIT tradition going back to… Thomas Jefferson |publisher=MIT News Office |date=June 8, 2001 |accessdate=2011-04-18 |quote=MIT's founder, [[William Barton Rogers]], regarded the practice of giving honorary degrees as 'literary almsgiving …of spurious merit and noisy popularity.'}}</ref> Summer attendees, exchange students, and auditing students are excluded from this list. Those who hold certificates or studied as non-degree students at MIT are also excluded.
The long-term faculty members consist of [[Academic tenure|tenure]] or tenure-track and equivalent academic positions, while short-term academic staff consist of lecturers (without tenure), [[postdoctoral researcher]]s (postdocs), visiting professors or scholars (visitors), and equivalent academic positions. At MIT, the specific academic title solely determines the type of affiliation, regardless of the actual time the position was held by a laureate.
Further explanations on visitors under short-term academic staff are presented as follows. 1) All informal or personal visits are excluded from the list; 2) all employment-based visiting positions, which carry teaching or research duties, are included as affiliations in the list; and, 3) as for award or honor-based visiting positions, to minimize controversy this list takes a conservative view and includes the positions as affiliations only if the laureates were required to assume employment-level duty (teaching or research) or the laureates specifically classified the visiting positions as "affiliation" or similar in reliable sources such as their [[curriculum vita]]. To be specific, visiting positions such as the "Arthur D. Little Memorial Visiting Lectureship" are awards or honors or recognition without employment-level duty, and thus will not be counted in this list.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://libraries.mit.edu/archives/exhibits/adlittle/mit-connection.html|title=Arthur D. Little,Inc.: Exhibits: Institute Archives & Special Collections: MIT|website=libraries.mit.edu|access-date=2018-02-18}}</ref> In case of "Arthur D. Little Visiting Professorship", visiting professors do spend several weeks on campus, but the professorship does not require inherent employment-level duty,<ref>{{cite web |title=Postdoc T.Y. Shen Honors his Wife |url=https://chemistry.mit.edu/support-chemistry/meet-our-major-supporters/postdoc-t-y-shen-honors-his-wife/ |publisher=MIT |accessdate=31 October 2019}}</ref> and thus are generally excluded from this list. In some cases, Arthur D. Little visiting professors do get involved in teaching or research; in such cases, they are included. In particular, attending meetings and giving public lectures, talks or non-curricular seminars is not a form of employment-level duty. This list also exclude those who held non-academic positions (for instance, advisory committee, administrative staff, etc.) at MIT. Finally, summer visitors are generally excluded from the list unless summer work yielded significant end products such as research publications and components of Nobel-winning work, since summer terms are not part of formal academic years.
{| class="wikitable" |+Some attendees and visitors not qualified as official academic affiliates !Name !Noble Prize !Year !Role in MIT |- |[[Mario Capecchi]] |Physiology or Medicine |2007 |Capecchi was an undergraduate student at [[Antioch College]], which had "work-study program"; as a student of Antioch, he spent several quarters at MIT.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/medicine/laureates/2007/capecchi-bio.html|title=Mario R. Capecchi - Biographical|website=www.nobelprize.org|access-date=2018-02-06}}</ref> This program was not a degree program and is equivalent to a student-exchange program. |- |[[Claude Cohen-Tannoudji]] |Physics |1997 |Visiting professor in 1976 (classified under "special lecturer" in his C.V.)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.phys.ens.fr/~cct/anglais/cv_e.htm|title=Cohen-Tannoudji Claude|website=www.phys.ens.fr|access-date=2017-12-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://infinitehistory.mit.edu/video/claude-cohen-tannoudji-coll%C3%A8ge-de-france-atom-photon-interactions%E2%80%9D-mit-physics-department|title=Claude Cohen-Tannoudji (Collège de France), "Atom-Photon Interactions" - MIT Physics Department Special Seminar 4/29/1992|website=mit.edu|accessdate=18 October 2019}}</ref> |- |[[William A. Fowler]] |Physics |1983 |Visiting professor in March–May 26, 1966; he delivered a series of lectures "Nuclear Astrophysics and Geophysics"<ref name=":187">{{cite web|url=https://history.aip.org/phn/11509026.html|title=Fowler, William A.|website=history.aip.org|access-date=2017-12-28}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{cite web|url=https://libraries.mit.edu/archives/mithistory/presidents-reports/1966.pdf|title=MIT (Report of the President 1966)|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=PAg3AQAAIAAJ&pg=PA1279&lpg=PA1279&dq=WILLIAM+A.+FOWLER+1966+MIT+VISITING#v=onepage&q=WILLIAM%20A.%20FOWLER%201966%20MIT%20VISITING&f=false|title=Independent Offices Appropriations for Fiscal Year 1967: Hearings Before the Subcommittee ... Committee on Appropriations, Senate, Eighty-ninth Congress, Second Session, on H.R. 14921|last=Appropriations|first=United States Congress Senate Committee on|date=1966|publisher=U.S. Government Printing Office}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oac.cdlib.org/findaid/ark:/13030/kt2d5nb7kj/entire_text/|title=Guide to the Papers of William A. Fowler, 1917-1994|website=oac.cdlib.org|access-date=2019-10-19}}</ref> |- |[[Ernst Otto Fischer]] |Chemistry |1973 |Arthur D. Little Visiting Professor (Spring 1973)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nobelprize.org/prizes/chemistry/1973/fischer/biographical/|title=The Nobel Prize in Chemistry 1973|website=NobelPrize.org|access-date=2019-10-15}}</ref> |- |[[Derek Barton]] |Chemistry |1969 |Arthur D. Little Visiting Professor (Spring 1958; he held the professorship for five weeks)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nobelprize.org/prizes/chemistry/1969/barton/biographical/|title=The Nobel Prize in Chemistry 1969|website=NobelPrize.org|access-date=2019-10-15}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cotton|first=F. Albert|date=2000|title=Derek H. R. Barton, 8 September 1918 · 16 March 1998|journal=Proceedings of the American Philosophical Society|volume=144|issue=3|pages=292–296|issn=0003-049X|jstor=1515591}}</ref> |- |[[Edward Victor Appleton]] |Physics |1947 |Arthur D. Little Memorial Lecturer (1946)<ref>{{cite journal |title=Science, Government and Industry in Britain |journal=Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists |date=December 1, 1946 |volume=2 |issue=11 |pages=2–5 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=GwwAAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA2&dq=Edward+V.+Appleton+Arthur+Dehon+Little+Memorial+Lectureship#v=onepage&q=Edward%20V.%20Appleton%20Arthur%20Dehon%20Little%20Memorial%20Lectureship&f=false|doi=10.1080/00963402.1946.11458055 |bibcode=1946BuAtS...2k...2A |last1=Appleton |first1=Edward V. }}</ref> |}
=== Affiliated organizations === The [[MIT Radiation Laboratory]] was established on October 11, 1940 and was officially terminated on December 31, 1945.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Saad|first=T. A.|date=October 1990|title=The story of the MIT Radiation Laboratory|journal=IEEE Aerospace and Electronic Systems Magazine|volume=5|issue=10|pages=46–51|doi=10.1109/62.60678}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://www.aps.org/programs/outreach/history/historicsites/mit.cfm|title=MIT Radiation Laboratory|website=www.aps.org|access-date=2019-10-19}}</ref> This war-time laboratory was funded and overseen by [[Alfred Lee Loomis]], whose wartime role was the head of Radar Division of the [[National Defense Research Committee]] (NDRC).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasonline.org/publications/biographical-memoirs/memoir-pdfs/loomis-alfred.pdf|title=Alfred Lee Loomis|last=|first=|date=|website=National Academy of Sciences|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasonline.org/publications/biographical-memoirs/memoir-pdfs/ramsey-norman.pdf|title=Norman F. Ramsey|last=|first=|date=|website=National Academy of Sciences|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}}</ref> [[Lee Alvin DuBridge]], the 2nd President of [[California Institute of Technology]], was the director of the lab, and Nobel laureate [[Isidor Isaac Rabi]] was the associate director.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://history.aip.org/phn/11507004.html|title=DuBridge, Lee A. (Lee Alvin), 1901-1994|website=history.aip.org|access-date=2019-10-19}}</ref><ref name=":264" /> The lab was primarily responsible for the research and development of [[radar]] and [[microwave]] technology.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /> As the Radiation Laboratory was not managed by or affiliated with the military, Nobel laureates who were affiliated with this war-time lab as researchers are generally considered as academic affiliates of MIT and thus are included in this list.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.mit.edu/physics/about/history/1971-2010.html|title=MIT Department of Physics|website=web.mit.edu|access-date=2019-10-19}}</ref> Exceptions include those who held military positions (non-academic) in the lab and those who participated ''only'' in military projects.
The [[MIT Lincoln Laboratory]] was established in 1951, with its roots in the MIT Radiation lab.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ll.mit.edu/about/history|title=History {{!}} MIT Lincoln Laboratory|website=www.ll.mit.edu|access-date=2019-10-19}}</ref> Nobel laureates who were affiliates of this lab as researchers are generally considered as academic affiliates of MIT and thus are included in this list. Exceptions include those who held military positions (non-academic) in the lab and those who participated ''only'' in military projects.
{| class="wikitable" |+Visitors and staff not qualified as official academic affiliates !Name !Noble Prize !Year !Role in MIT |- |[[Paul Greengard]] |Physiology or Medicine |2000 |[[Electronics]] technician from [[U.S. navy|U.S. Navy]] (military, non-academic) at MIT during [[World War II]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.rockefeller.edu/news/25634-pioneering-neuroscientist-nobel-laureate-paul-greengard-dies-93|title=Celebrating and remembering Paul Greengard, a pioneering neuroscientist and Nobel laureate|website=News|access-date=2019-10-19}}</ref><ref name=":555">{{cite web|url=https://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/medicine/laureates/2000/greengard-bio.html|title=Paul Greengard - Biographical|website=www.nobelprize.org|accessdate=2017-04-28}}</ref> |- |[[Jack Steinberger]] |Physics |1988 |War-time military researcher from [[U.S. Army]] at MIT Radiation Lab (1942-1944) during World War II<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nobelprize.org/prizes/physics/1988/steinberger/biographical/|title=The Nobel Prize in Physics 1988|website=NobelPrize.org|access-date=2019-10-16}}</ref><ref name=":179">{{cite web|url=https://history.aip.org/phn/11604036.html|title=Steinberger, J.|website=history.aip.org|access-date=2017-12-22}}</ref> |- |[[Willis Lamb]] |Physics |1955 |Researcher at MIT Radiation Laboratory, [[Columbia University]] Satellite (1943-1945){{efn|name=Lamb|From 1943 to 1945, [[Willis E. Lamb]] was a researcher at Columbia Radiation Laboratory at [[Columbia University]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://history.aip.org/phn/11604013.html|title=Lamb, Willis E. (Willis Eugene), 1913-2008|website=history.aip.org|access-date=2018-01-04}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nobelprize.org/prizes/physics/1955/lamb/biographical/|title=Willis E. Lamb - Biographical|website=NobelPrize.org|access-date=2019-10-18}}</ref> which was a satellite lab supporting the main Radiation Lab at MIT during [[World War II]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=De Bary |first1=Wm. Theodore |last2=De Bary |first2=William Theodore |title=Living Legacies at Columbia |year=2006 |publisher=Columbia University Press |isbn=0231138849 |pages=226 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=l1os3mwQkxYC&pg=PA226&lpg=PA226&dq=Willis+E.+Lamb+MIT+Radiation+Lab#v=onepage&q=Willis%20E.%20Lamb%20MIT%20Radiation%20Lab&f=false}}</ref>}} |- |[[Edwin McMillan]] |Chemistry |1951 |Researcher working on military work at MIT Radiation Lab (1940-1941) during World War II<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasonline.org/publications/biographical-memoirs/memoir-pdfs/mcmillan-edwin.pdf|title=Edwin McMillan|last=|first=|date=|website=National Academy of Sciences|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}}</ref><ref name=":451">{{cite web|url=https://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/chemistry/laureates/1951/mcmillan-bio.html|title=Edwin M. McMillan - Biographical|website=www.nobelprize.org|access-date=2018-01-28}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://history.aip.org/phn/11411002.html|title=McMillan, Edwin M. (Edwin Mattison), 1907-|website=history.aip.org|access-date=2019-10-15}}</ref> |}
== Summary == {{see also|List of Nobel laureates by university affiliation}} According to Wikipedia policies on [[wikipedia:No original research|no original research]] and [[wikipedia:Neutral point of view|objectivity/neutrality]], it is not possible in Wikipedia to assign various weights to different types of affiliations. Hence, all types of affiliations count equally in the following table and throughout the whole page.
In the following list, the number following a person's name is the year they received the prize; in particular, a number with asterisk (*) means the person received the award while they were working at MIT (including [[Emeritus|emeritus staff]]). <u>A name underlined</u> implies that this person has already been listed in a previous category (i.e., multiple affiliations). The table doesn't provide [[Wikipedia:Citing sources|citations]] or details on entries; for citations and details, see "Nobel laureates by category".

== Nobel laureates by category ==
=== Nobel laureates in Physics === {| class="wikitable sortable" !Name !Year !Affiliation with MIT |- |[[Didier Queloz]] |2019 |Visiting Scientist at MIT Kavli Institute for Astrophysics and Space Research<ref>{{cite web |title=Congratulations To MKI Visiting Scientist Didier Queloz For Being Awarded The 2019 Nobel Prize In Physics! |url=https://space.mit.edu/congratulations-to-mki-visiting-scientist-didier-queloz-for-being-awarded-the-2019-nobel-prize-in-physics/ |publisher=MIT |accessdate=31 October 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Queloz, Didier |url=https://space.mit.edu/people/queloz-didier/ |publisher=MIT |accessdate=31 October 2019}}</ref> |- |[[Rainer Weiss]] |2017 |B.S. (1955) and Ph.D. in Physics (1962); Assistant Professor of Physics (1964–1967), Associate Professor of Physics (1967–1973), Professor of Physics (1973–2001), and Professor of Physics, Emeritus (2001–present)<ref>{{cite web |title=Weiss, Rainer |url=https://history.aip.org/phn/11603006.html |publisher=The American Institute of Physics |accessdate=31 October 2019}}</ref> |- |[[Serge Haroche]] |2012 |Visiting Scientist (1979)<ref>{{cite web |title=Curriculum Vitae (Serge Haroche) |url=https://www.college-de-france.fr/media/serge-haroche/UPL5355231640689524500_Haroche_Notice.2011.PDF |website=college-de-france.fr |accessdate=15 October 2019}}</ref> |- |[[Adam Riess]] |2011 |B.S<ref>{{cite web |title=Curriculum Vitae (Adam Guy Riess) |url=http://www.stsci.edu/~ariess/documents/Adam_Riess_Resume_CV.pdf |website=stsci.edu |accessdate=15 October 2019}}</ref> |- |[[George Smoot]] |2006 |B.S, PhD<ref>{{cite web |title=Curriculum Vitae (George F. Smoot) |url=http://pariscosmo.in2p3.fr/sites/default/files/Smoot%20CVJun2016_L.pdf |website=http://pariscosmo.in2p3.fr |accessdate=15 October 2019}}</ref> |- |[[Frank Wilczek]] |2004 |Herman Feshbach Professor of Physics (September 2000–present)<ref>{{cite web |title=Wilczek, Frank |url=https://history.aip.org/phn/11604015.html |publisher=The American Institute of Physics |accessdate=31 October 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Curriculum Vitae (Frank Wilczek) |url=http://web.mit.edu/physics/people/faculty/docs/wilczek_cv.pdf |publisher=MIT |accessdate=15 October 2019}}</ref> |- |[[Carl Wieman]] |2001 |B.S<ref>{{cite web |title=Curriculum Vitae (Carl Edwin Wieman) |url=http://www.cwsei.ubc.ca/Files/CurrentVitaCEW.pdf |website=ubc.ca |accessdate=15 October 2019}}</ref> |- |[[Eric Cornell]] |2001 |PhD<ref name=":141">{{cite web|url=http://jila.colorado.edu/bec/CornellGroup/CornellCV.pdf|title=CV (Eric A. Cornell)|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref> |- |[[Wolfgang Ketterle]] |2001 |Professor<ref name=":142">{{cite web|url=http://www.rle.mit.edu/cua_pub/ketterle_group/group_info/WK/CV%20WK.pdf|title=CV (Wolfgang Ketterle)|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref> |- |[[Daniel Tsui]] |1998 |Visiting Scientist (1988)<ref name=":151">{{Cite news|url=https://news.mit.edu/1998/nobel-1021|title=Winners of Nobel Prize in physics have roots at MIT|work=MIT News|access-date=2017-12-21}}</ref> |- |[[Horst Störmer]] |1998 |Visiting Scientist at Francis Bitter High Magnetic Field Lab<ref name=":151" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nobelprize.org/prizes/physics/1998/stormer/biographical/|title=The Nobel Prize in Physics 1998|website=NobelPrize.org|access-date=2019-10-15}}</ref> |- |[[Robert Laughlin]] |1998 |PhD<ref name=":149">{{cite web|url=http://large.stanford.edu/history/|title=R. B. Laughlin - Professional History|website=large.stanford.edu|access-date=2017-12-21}}</ref> |- |[[William D. Phillips]] |1997 |PhD; Postdoctoral Researcher<ref name=":156">{{cite web|url=http://www.giovannipastore.it/index_file/PhillipsCV.pdf|title=CV (William D. Phillips)|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref> |- |[[Clifford Shull]] |1994 |Professor of Physics (1955–1986) and Professor of Physics Emeritus (1986–2001)<ref>{{cite web |title=Shull, Clifford Glenwood |url=https://history.aip.org/phn/11604034.html |publisher=The American Institute of Physics |accessdate=31 October 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Clifford G. Shull - Biographical |url=https://www.nobelprize.org/prizes/physics/1994/shull/biographical/ |publisher=Nobel Foundation |accessdate=31 October 2019}}</ref> |- |[[Henry W. Kendall]] |1990 |PhD; Professor<ref name=":169">{{cite web|url=https://history.aip.org/phn/11603001.html|title=Kendall, Henry W. Winding Up at the Radiation Lab, Going to Harvard, and Marriage|journal=Foundations of Physics|volume=29|issue=7|pages=1119–1162|doi=10.1023/A:1018841800257|issn=1572-9516}}</ref> |- |[[Charles Townes]] |1964 |Professor of Physics<ref name=":229">{{cite web|url=https://history.aip.org/phn/11408013.html|title=Townes, Charles H.|website=history.aip.org|access-date=2018-01-03}}</ref> |- |[[Donald Glaser]] |1960 |Visiting Professor of Biophysics (For a semester starting in January 1962)<ref>{{cite book|title=The Legacy of Alladi Ramakrishnan in the Mathematical Sciences|last1=Alladi|first1=Krishnaswami|website=|year=2010|isbn=978-1-4419-6262-1|pages=25–65|chapter=Telegrams Received for the MATSCIENCE Inauguration|doi=10.1007/978-1-4419-6263-8_3|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite document|url=http://digitalassets.lib.berkeley.edu/roho/ucb/text/glaser_donald.pdf|author=Vettel, Eric|title=Donald Glaser: The Bubble Chamber, Bioengineering, Business Consulting, and Neurobiology – an oral history conducted in 2003–2004 | publisher=Regional Oral History Office, The Bancroft Library, University of California, Berkeley|year=2006|accessdate=2013-03-02}}</ref> |- |[[William Shockley]] |1956 |PhD<ref name=":246">{{cite web|url=https://history.aip.org/phn/11605007.html|title=Shockley, William, 1910-1989|website=history.aip.org|access-date=2018-01-04}}</ref> |- |[[Max Born]] |1954 |Visiting "Foreign Lecturer" at MIT (14 November 1925 to 22 January 1926){{efn|From 14 November 1925 to 22 January 1926, [[Max Born]] delivered two series of lectures on [[Quantum mechanics|quantum theory]] at MIT. Born was one of the first physicists to write a paper on then newly developed theory of [[quantum mechanics]] that was published in the United States. The [[matrix mechanics]], developed by [[Werner Heisenberg]], was developed for dealing with discrete energy spectra. At MIT, Born and [[Norbert Wiener]], a professor of mathematics, developed a general operator calculus that could be applied to both discrete and continuous case, and published their work in ''[[Journal of Mathematical Physics|The Journal of Mathematical Physics]]'' in February 1926. They were able to solve a continuum problem, namely the motion of a free particle in one dimension. Later, their work were superseded. However, Born's work on continuum problems was important for his later discovery of the statistical interpretation of the [[wavefunction]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pais|first=Abraham|date=December 17, 1982|title=Max Born's Statistical Interpretation of Quantum Mechanics|journal=Proceedings of the American Philosophical Society|volume=218|issue=4578|pages=1193–1198|jstor=1688979}}</ref> His two sets of lectures at MIT were published in ''Problems of Atomic Dynamics'' (See "Bibliography").}}<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=anD0BwAAQBAJ&pg=PA117&dq=Foreign+Lecturer+MIT+Max+Born#v=onepage&q=Foreign%20Lecturer%20MIT%20Max%20Born&f=false|title=Norbert Wiener 1894–1964|last=Masani|first=Pesi R.|date=2012-12-06|publisher=Birkhäuser|isbn=9783034892520}}</ref> |- |[[Edward M. Purcell]] |1952 |Researcher at MIT Radiation Lab (1941-1946)<ref name=":255">{{cite web|url=https://history.aip.org/phn/11603005.html|title=Purcell, Edward M.|website=history.aip.org|access-date=2018-01-05}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ed-thelen.org/EdwardMPurcell-interview-.html|title=EDWARD M. PURCELL|website=ed-thelen.org|access-date=2019-10-19}}</ref> |- |[[Isidor Rabi]] |1944 |Associate Director of MIT Radiation Lab (1942-1945)<ref name=":264">{{cite web|url=https://history.aip.org/phn/11407006.html|title=Rabi, I. I. (Isidor Isaac), 1898-1988|website=history.aip.org|access-date=2018-01-05}}</ref> |}
